"As for North Carolina, we considered moving Cooper's race against Lt. Gov. Dan Forest to Likely Democratic, given Cooper's frequent double-digit leads in the polls. But the state has a long list of competitive races this year, including the presidential contest, so to be cautious, we're keeping the race at Lean Democratic." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-29/analysis-republicans-maintain-edge-in-governor-races
fivethirtyeight

"Cooper, who narrowly won in 2016, faces Lt. Gov. Dan Forest in a bid for a second term. Cooper has made a series of tough decisions due to the coronavirus, and so far, North Carolinians seem to be giving him credit for his efforts. Recent polls show Cooper ahead by between five and 19 points, a margin well ahead of Democratic presidential nominee Biden in the state. Forest has tried to raise his profile by suing Cooper over his handling of the virus; the lieutenant governor has also questioned the effectiveness of masks and said he will not mandate them if he wins. Cooper has responded with TV ads chastising Forest for holding crowded, in-person events. For now, Cooperâ€™s approach seems to be serving him well. Indeed, in multiple polls, a durable 8% to 12% of voters indicate support for both Trump and Cooper. Because North Carolina is a purple state, weâ€™re not ready to move this race to Likely Democratic, but itâ€™s clearly leaning in Cooperâ€™s direction." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-13/analysis-republicans-look-poised-to-maintain-edge-in-governors-mansions

From a Cook Political report update out today: "In North Carolina, Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper remains the favorite for reelection with a hefty fundraising advantage â€” and steady polling lead â€” over Republican Lt. Gov. Dan Forest. Forest has come under fire for remarks he's made disparaging the efficacy of mask-wearing that Democrats have exploited. The closeness of the Tar Heel State as the ultimate swing state this election means this one may never be comfortably put away for Cooper. Still, he is running the best of any statewide Democrat on the ballot, and it remains in the Lean Democratic column." https://cookpolitical.com/analysis/governors/governors-overview/governors-updates-rating-changes-missouri-and-vermont

Cooper has been up double digits in polls for months https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/north-carolina/.
Cooper's COVID response only seems to be helping him in the polls [1], and he consistently leads Forest, who was just forced to drop his sideshow lawsuit [2].

Maintaining my current projection. Forest hasn't been up in a single poll this year (he did come out even in one June poll), and most pollsters have Cooper up by double digits. With less than 80 days left before the election and Cooper maintaining his demanding lead for months with no apparent momentum change upcoming, it would be a dramatic upset for Forest to pull this one out. I'm not saying it's impossible, NC is definitely purple leaning red in many places and polls are not always right on the money, but the data suggests it won't be a kind November for the Republican candidate.

I'm trying something different with this prediction - I'm trying to teach myself how to use Bayes' Theorem. My intent is that this will establish a reasonable baseline *from which to adjust* that is more accurate than starting with a simple 50/50 and adjusting from there.
The incumbent will win, with the unaffiliated votes going democratic

Looking at the history of gubernatorial races since 1948, and the percentage of times the incumbent won nationally (72.08%), then using Bayes formula to account for variance in gubernatorial races in the Southeast (68.97%), and then again for North Carolina gubernatorial races specifically (26.3%), I get to 56% in favor of Cooper. There are other factors to keep an eye on, specifically the COVID19 response and reception by voters. Another factor is individual contributions to each candidate. So far those favor Cooper (very) roughly 8:1.
Strong incumbent candidate
Four of the last five governors in North Carolina have been Democrats.

Considering we (I live in NC) ousted the GOP Governor over transgender bathroom bill and the resulting shame - yet NC still managed to maintain GOP control overall in the state. Cooper has done a commendable job handling the pandemic in a non-partisan manner During an election year in a swing state, guided in part by the endless well of doctors and scientists on hand locally (Duke, UNC, Wake Forest, etc). His team has also done an excellent job of avoiding resorting to partisan tactics or threats when groups presented challenges in court to his pandemic restrictions (Bars, churches, gyms, etc). He is also a moderate and has a calm and pleasant demeanor. All of this, IMO, will continue to ensure his place as Governor.
